learning_outcomes.description: Understand current issues in the field of second language acquisition from an Australian and international perspective.
Effectively analyse, organise and communicate the main theoretical concepts and methodological practice current in the field.
Identify and address problems and come up with creative solutions to current issues in second language acquisition and use.
Understand how the acquisition and use of second language(s)mediates  knowledge of other cultures and societies.
To create and evaluate student-built materials consolidating and sharing the knowledge gained from weekly lectures.

assessments.assessment_title: Ripple: Material creation, evaluation and reflection
assessments.due_date:
22/05/2026 4:00 pm

WEEK 12

RIPPLE learning materials are due weekly, with a 2 week window in which to submit (so the RIPPLE task for Week 1 must be submitted by Week 3, Week 2 in Week 4, etc.), with the exception of Week 12's content that must be completed before Friday Week 12.
assessments.task_description:
RIPPLE is a technology developed through UQ that allows students to create learning materials, and have other students rate these materials for their effectiveness.

SLAT7805 will use of RIPPLE as a weekly ongoing assessment. This will work as an 'enhanced' version of a learning journal / weekly reflection of the type usually offered through Blackboard in other courses (e.g., SLAT7806).

This assessment is in TWO PARTS.

PART 1

Each week, students must create a set of learning materials based on a question posed by the course coordinator. These will be in the form of an "AI prompt reflection", where you will use your preferred generative AI application to engage with the weekly question, noting the prompts used, the generative AI output, and your evaluation of the output in terms of its accuracy and impact on your own beliefs. Alternatively, you may use the 'notes' function to answer the weekly question, supplementing your answer with links to useful videos, journal articles, or other online resources. There is no minimum or maximum word limit on these submissions. Students will receive guidance, examples and training in the Week 1 tutorial about how to create these materials and upload them to the RIPPLE platform. The learning materials should be designed so as to be useful for MA-level students in understanding SLAT7805 course content. 

There are 12 weeks of content in SLAT7805, and students must complete at least 10 sets of learning materials to pass SLAT7805. RIPPLE tracks the number of materials students create. You have two weeks to complete each weeks' content from the Monday that week begins.

In addition, there is a short evaluation component for other students' learning materials. All SLAT7805 students should evaluate at least three other students' learning materials per week, for a minimum of 30 evaluations required to pass SLAT7805. Again, training on how to evaluate other's materials will be provided in the Week 1 tutorial. RIPPLE tracks the number of evaluations students complete. 

Students' evaluations will leave a 'ranking' for the created learning materials, and students can use these materials to help them better understand weekly content.

This part of the assessment is a PASS/FAIL hurdle - you MUST complete the 10 learning materials / 30 moderations or you cannot pass this assessment.

---------------------------------------

PART 2

For the REFLECTION part of the assessment, students need to produce a VIDEO REFLECTION on the process and outcomes of creating their learning materials and evaluating the materials of others. Students should:

A) Comment specifically on ONE of their highest-ranked sets of learning materials and explain why/how these materials were chosen and how they might improve others' knowledge of SLAT7827 course content

B) Comment on TWO specific sets of learning materials supplied by others that the student ranked highly or found particularly useful, and how these improved the student's knowledge of SLAT7827 course content.

This video reflection should be approximately 5 minutes long. A link to upload the video will be given in the relevant 'assessment' folder in the course Blackboard site, with instructions also provided by your tutor prior to upload. A PPT is permitted to show the learning materials you are talking about as well as any references you want to provide but you CANNOT read out your reflection from a PPT - when giving your reflection, you must simply talk to the camera showing your face in full screen mode.

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission is via RIPPLE platform, link is available in Blackboard/Learn.UQ
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: No late submission permitted - a reminder e-mail will be sent to anyone who has not completed their resources/moderated others' resources in Week 12 to ensure completion.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
TASK OVERVIEW

You will receive a short sample of unseen learner language data (8–12 lines). You will be assigned ONE set only, with the assignment provided in Week 5. The dataset may be taken from:

  • Adult L2 learner data
  • A short transcript from a classroom exchange
  • A list of learner-produced sentences illustrating a pattern

Your task is to:

a) Identify 2–3 linguistic features relevant to acquisition (e.g., phonology, vocabulary (lexis), syntax, morphology, semantics, pragmatics, word order, negation, question formation, inflection, etc.) (approximately 150 words). A “feature” refers to a systematic pattern evident across the data (not isolated errors), such as developmental sequencing, overgeneralisation, omission, or form–function mismatch, etc. You will be given a table to complete for this part of the assessment.

b) Explain the features using TWO SLA theories covered in Weeks 1–6. (approximately 300 words each = 600 words). The two theories selected must come from different theoretical traditions (e.g. one generative/structural (e.g. UG/Error Analysis/Contrastive Analysis) and one functional/interactionist/behaviourist/cognitive; or one cognitive, one interactionist, etc.). A 'cheat sheet' about each theory and what it claims/does not claim about learner language will be provided for you to help you.

c) Argue which theory better accounts for the learner’s linguistic behaviour (or, vice versa, which theory cannot account for this behaviour), using a personal (but critical) reflection (500 words). In your reflection, explicitly consider at least two of the following: explanatory power, treatment of variability/errors, learnability assumptions, and pedagogical implications. “Personal” refers to your reasoned evaluation as an emerging SLA scholar, rather than anecdotal teaching experience or unsupported opinion.

The total word count is 1250 words with 10% +/- allowed.

Theories you may refer to (anything covered in Weeks 1-6, although content from Week 7 may be permitted):

  • Behaviourism
  • Universal grammar (UG)
  • Error analysis
  • Contrastive analysis
  • Interactionist approaches (e.g. input, negotiation for meaning, output)
  • Functionalist approaches (e.g. basic variety, interlanguage)
  • Cognitive approaches (e.g. skill acquisition, processability, usage-based)

Assessment Criteria

You will be evaluated on your ability to:

  • a) Accurately analyse unfamiliar language data (25%)
  • b) Apply SLA theories correctly and critically (25%)
  • c) Compare theories with clear reasoning (25%)
  • d) Provide a personal but justified argument (25%)

The rubric for grades 1-7 can be found in the 'assessment' folder.

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
29/05/2026 4:00 pm

Written component is available from Monday, WEEK 13 and due 4pm, Friday WEEK 13
assessments.task_description:
Final quiz questions to be released to students on Monday Week 13 via Blackboard Test, to be completed by 4pm on Friday Week 13. 

The assessment will be composed of 6 short-answer questions (between 200-250 words) assigned at random from a larger pool of questions. Your answers to these questions will be worth a maximum 40 marks (total word count = 1,200-1,500). The questions will be based on key points of content across all weeks of SLAT7805, but answers must be personalised as your apply your knowledge of SLA theories to you own language learning/teaching experiences; course materials or RIPPLE discussions; or specific case studies or scenarios discussed in class. Note: Aside from submitting your work to Blackboard Test, you also need to submit an electronic copy of your written work in MS Word or equivalent to Turnitin for a plagarism/AI check.

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies to support their preparation, such use must be appropriately acknowledged or referenced in line with UQ’s academic integrity expectations. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

The use of RIPPLE resources to assist with preparing your written responses is permitted and does not require citation or referencing. 

Successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. Indeed, to pass this assessment, students are required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission during a follow-up one-on-one interview independent of AI and MT tools. The interview will be conducted live (in person or via Zoom), and the use of generative AI or MT tools will therefore not be permitted during the interview itself. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit written answers via Blackboard Test AND Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
8/06/2026 - 12/06/2026

Follow-up interview conducted in person/live via Zoom during Exam period. Students will sign up for an interview timeslot. This component needs to be completed by 5pm Friday, Exam Week 2.
assessments.task_description:
This interview provides an opportunity for you to articulate your understanding of key SLA concepts discussed in the Final Quiz Assessment, and reflect on how your thinking has evolved through the course. You will be asked to discuss your responses to the written questions for the Final Quiz and consider how the theories and frameworks explored in SLAT7805 have influenced your perspective on second language learning. The interview also serves as a checkpoint to support academic integrity by confirming the authenticity of the submitted work. 

This one-on-one (in-person/live via Zoom) interview does not carry a separate weighting but instead functions as academic integrity hurdle requirements (PASS/FAIL). While the interview is not weighted, it will be assessed against specific criteria. Guidelines and marking criteria will be made available to students via Blackboard. 

Each interview will take approximately 10 minutes. Participation in this interview is a mandatory component of the assessment. Students will be required to present UQ ID card for this interview.  

The interview will be recorded in line with UQ’s policy on recording oral and practical assessment. 

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies to support their preparation, such use must be appropriately acknowledged or referenced in line with UQ’s academic integrity expectations. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

The use of RIPPLE resources to assist with preparing your written responses is permitted and does not require citation or referencing. 

Successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. Indeed, to pass this assessment, students are required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission during a follow-up one-on-one interview independent of AI and MT tools. The interview will be conducted live (in person or via Zoom), and the use of generative AI or MT tools will therefore not be permitted during the interview itself. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Follow-up interview conducted in person/live via Zoom during Exam period. Students will sign up for an interview timeslot. This component needs to be completed by 5pm Friday, EXAM WEEK 2.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
